children.subject: ^^ also why double major? just take the classes you want in the other major if you're really interested. it's less stress
then you should consider taking less units if possible... better grades...better health :/

Hi OP! I'm an alumnus who had a very similar experience to you because I too had (1) another major which I did much better in (economics), (2) felt bewilderment as to why I was underperforming on exams, (3) test anxiety, (4) lots of units every semester, and (5) had a tough time in the 61A/B. All together, it's a frightening mix, but it can be solved. Let's break down how to improve things in three stages: before the exam, during the exam, and after the exam. Note: it's important not to try to nail all of these habits down at once. Pick up one habit, master it, and then move on to the next one. It took me most of junior year to incorporate some of the things mentioned below. If you can master two a month, that's pretty good.

Before the exam:

-Understand the tradeoffs in your schedule. You're going to have minor bumps in your GPA if you add "easy" classes, as I know you're trying to improve your GPA. If you know what you want to do for graduate school, narrow your focus on neurobiological classes and experience. I don't think any double major will require you to take 18-20 units a semester, so something tells me that you can hone your focus.

-Attend lecture. Professor Dragan in CS188 often quoted that people who attend lecture have ~30% better retention and understanding of material. I only learned this my senior year, but I didn't feel lost in even the most confusing of classes. In a similar vein...

-Develop routines. It convinced a night owl to start sleeping before 2 and to feel refreshed when hiking all the way across campus for my 8AM. Even during quarantine, when everyone's sleep schedules are out of wack, try to maintain a consistent sleeping routine because you can.

-Review lectures within 1-2 days. I wish I could say I did this consistently, but my roommate can vouch for it. Here is the retention rates of memorization. The way I looked at it is you could either (a) spend an hour now to understand a difficult concept or (b) spend 2-3 hours understanding a difficult concept a couple weeks from now. That's a pretty solid return on investment.

-Develop a study schedule and stick to it. Start studying maybe a week in advance, so it doesn't feel like a crunch. A solid study schedule, with a one day buffer before the exam, prevented me from falling into panic mode. 

-Test yourself when it matters least. If you don't think you understand a concept while studying, quiz yourself then and there. You can either learn the material before the exam, or during it (can't say I fully remembered the Regex rules from CS61B...)

-Express any questions or concerns with TAs, professors, or on Piazza. Same reason as the above point. You learn faster collectively, and when I lived in OH during CS189, I picked up mistakes I was making that I couldn't have predicted until too late.

During the exam:

-Do the easy stuff first. Plain and simple, all points are weighed equally, and you can build momentum.

-Remember your first cause while spiraling. I've spiraled during exams. My thought process went from "This is hard" => "I don't know this" => "Everyone else around me is writing vigorously" => "They must know the answer" => "I'm gonna fail" ...and so forth. I've spiraled, just like anyone else. But what you can practice is what caused you to spiral. It's because you didn't know the problem. Which leads me to...

-Take it back to first principles. This is a tree problem, what are similar ones I know? How were those solved? What general strategies were used? Chances are, you've learned how to solve something similar, and there's an underlying lesson in each similar problem: use recursion, think of the base cases, can we memoize our results, and so forth. 

-Write down what you do know. Don't waste energy trying to organize all your strategies and thoughts. Write down leads or ideas you have, so you can at least demonstrate partial credit.

-Clock management. I had poor clock management because I would wrestle problems in order. You have to know when to move on or not. This is best practiced by locking yourself in a room, simulating test conditions, and timing practice exams. All of this comes with practice.

After the exam:

-Remember how you did via clock management and where studying helped and hurt you. Hindsight is useful for improving mistakes. "The definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over again, but expecting different results." -Albert Einstein

-Review your mistakes for final exams and interviews. Try cataloging them, as one could do with Leetcode or general algorithms problems.

-Understand the big picture. I'm still not a great test taker, but I'm still able to land interviews because I don't get asked about my GPA much. As for graduate school, someone who has applied can give better advice than me.

Hope this helps!

I’ll share some thoughts from my own experience in a technical major (not EECS/CS). Disclaimer - everyone’s situation is different so everything may not apply or work for you.

When I took 61AB, I could barely get an average score on exams but did okay on projects, which made me realize that I could get by with practical work without fully understanding the concepts. Ultimately I decided CS wasn’t for me because I didn’t enjoy it and only worked hard because I worried about my grade/future, rather than out of interest. After switching to a similar major and taking fewer classes each semester, my confidence improved because I cared more about what I was doing, had more time to learn the material, and got higher grades.

As for grad school, I’m not a CS major but was able to get into various masters programs (Berkeley, UCLA, etc) for my field with ~3.4 - the key was showing improvement over time, getting good research experience, and really explaining why I was prepared for grad school (despite what grades might suggest). I applied to a few programs with varying ranks because admission anywhere isn’t guaranteed, but it doesn’t hurt to try.

It’s easier said than done, but consider why you want to double major and determine if different strategies work for you - like perhaps doing a minor instead, taking fewer classes, building skills through research instead of classes, and so on. Making changes won’t lead to overnight results, but gradually it becomes better with experience and practice. Again, everyone is different, so my situation may not apply to you but hopefully helps a little!

history.content:
This is less of a question but more of advice/thoughts askance? (if this is the right place to ask this) 

I'm a second year double major in EECS and another rough and uncurved technical major and as far as exams go, I do WAYYYYY better raw score wise on the other major's exams than I do on CS exams even though I study my bum off for CS exams.

It's at the point where I'll help/ other people who don't get the material and tutor them while I'm taking the class, and then afterwards they end up doing better on an exam than I do. This comes from a combination of either being pretty sick to having really bad test anxiety (I don't think that's a thing???) and other reasons. I usually wouldn't be THAT much stock on exam grades but 1) they count so much towards our final grade and 2) grad schools care a lot about grades!!

Right now I have ~3.35 on around 18-20 units per semester (I started out in a really rough place after a terrible 61A experience that basically crushed my confidence and it's been slowly working up) and I have so many goals to work towards and I'm involved in some really interesting research and I'm working towards what I want out of uni and work. I still can't shake the feeling that even if I can keep improving my GPA every semester, I'll never be able to get into any grad programme or masters (I saw an earlier post that said the typical GPA would be 3.7-3.8 that sparked panic).

In terms of that, what are your guys' thoughts? My goal is to eventually reach graduate work in neurobiological signalling systems and neural networks (in brain and computational work).

Are there any tips or advice y'all have for a notoriously bad test taker and just in general thoughts?
history.subject: Exam/GPA Anxiety
